In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation of or 
reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the Asian Development Bank does 
not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  early  2010,  the  Government  of  Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG)  requested  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) technical assistance (TA) to complete the implementation of the 
National Public–Private Partnership (PPP) Policy approved by the National Executive Council in 
December 2008. The policy calls for the enactment of a PPP law and establishment of a center 
to  facilitate  the  preparation,  evaluation,  transaction,  and  implementation  of  PPP  projects. 
Greater private investment in the provision of infrastructure services, through direct investment 
as well as through PPPs, is an integral part of the government’s Development Strategic Plan, 
2010–2030 and Medium Term Development Plan, 2011–2015. It is also a central feature of the 
approach to supporting private sector development in ADB’s PNG country partnership strategy, 
2011–2015.1  
 
2.  A fact-finding mission in May 2010 resulted in a memorandum of understanding outlining 
the  agreed  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing 
arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA to be provided by ADB to the government's 
PPP program. The TA will build upon the work already supported by ADB in 2008–2010 to 
develop the PPP Policy, the legal and institutional framework for the future PPP program, and to 
prepare  the  state-owned  enterprise  (SOE)  sector  for  increased  competition.2 This  ongoing 
support has been instrumental in maintaining reform momentum. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Despite  a  rich  resource  base  and  high  levels  of  external  assistance,  PNG  social 
indicators lie below those of other countries with similar income per capita levels, and the 
country is not expected to meet any of the Millennium Development Goals by 2015. SOEs 
continue to dominate the provision of power, water, sewerage, seaports, and airports, crowding 
out private sector investment and not achieving targets. Massive infrastructure investment is 
required to pave the way for sustained economic growth, and these requirements far outstrip 
PNG’s fiscal resources, even with the advent of the Exxon Mobil-led PNG-Liquefied Natural Gas 
(LNG)  project.4 Even  if  all  the  additional  government  revenue  from  the  LNG  project  were 
allocated to infrastructure, this would not be enough to finance the country’s investment needs.5 
Moreover, it would not be prudent for the government of PNG to seek to finance all of its 
infrastructure investments from internal resources, given the leverage, innovation, and efficiency 
gains that can be secured from PPP arrangements, where properly structured.   
 
4.  The  government  recognizes  that  private  investment  is  critical  to  accelerating 
infrastructure modernization, and has been working to open up selected sectors to increased

2  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to Papua New Guinea for Policies for Private Sector Development. Manila (TA 
4722-PNG, closed in December 2009); ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Private Sector Development Initiative. 
Manila (TA 6353-REG); and ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for Private Sector Development Initiative Phase II. 
Manila (TA 7430-REG). 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 2 July 2010. 
4  This project is forecast to add 15%–20% to GDP during its 30-year life span, or to increase the annual gross 
national income by about 9% after accounting for anticipated income outflows. Over the project lifespan, PNG is 
expected to receive $5.6–$7.5 billion in royalties, development taxes and equity dividends, in addition to corporate 
tax revenue. This would represent close to $200 million per year, or approximately 30% of PNG’s average annual 
development expenditure budget.

2  
competition  and  to  establish  a  framework  to  facilitate  PPP  transactions.  The  government 
considers PPP transactions to be an important way of leveraging private capital and expertise 
and in some cases an alternative to full-scale privatization. While there is currently no legal 
obstacle to executing PPP transactions in PNG, the absence of a formal, transparent and 
predictable process for evaluating and processing PPP projects increases the risks and costs to 
private companies in what is already a high-cost business environment. A formal PPP process 
and program will reduce the risks of undue interference in the procurement process, facilitate 
the effective allocation of risks, and demonstrate that the government is actively seeking private 
investment in the provision of infrastructure services.  
 
5.  Important progress has been made to date on the PPP framework. This work, which was 
led by an interdepartmental task force and supported by ADB TA, resulted in a K1.5 million 
budget allocation for the new PPP center in 2011 and the finalization of a PPP bill. It is 
anticipated that this bill will be considered by parliament in the second quarter of 2011. Once the 
law is adopted, the PPP center will become a legal entity and can lead the development of a 
PPP program. Its first year of operations will be critical in establishing the credibility of the PPP 
program. The center will require very active collaboration with line agencies preparing PPP 
concepts, the Department of National Planning and Monitoring, and the Department of Treasury 
in building up its PPP financing and fiscal risk management capabilities. For the PPP program to 
be a success, future private sector partners will need to see that the government has the 
capacity to (i) identify and prepare bankable PPP projects, (ii) finance these projects, and (iii) 
serve as a viable PPP partner. 
 
6.  Previous efforts by the government to structure PPPs have had mixed results, largely 
because the allocation of risks has been poor. It is unclear whether this was a result of vested 
interests or simply a lack of technical capacity in structuring PPPs, but it has underscored the 
importance of establishing a robust project preparation and assessment process, integrating 
PPPs  into  the  government’s  fiscal  risk  management  considerations,  and  structuring  a 
mechanism to support long-term financing commitments.   
 
7.  The TA will facilitate private sector investment in infrastructure service provision in PNG 
through the development and implementation of a PPP program. To achieve this goal, the TA 
will strengthen the capacity of the government to prepare, transact, and implement PPP projects.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The expected impact of the TA is greater private investment in infrastructure services in 
PNG. This will be measured by the increased private sector share of total PNG investment in 
infrastructure.  
 
9.  The TA outcome will be improved capacity of the government to prepare and transact 
PPPs,  which  will  lend  credibility  to  the  PPP  program  and  create  opportunities  for  private 
investment  in  infrastructure.  By  the  end  of  the  TA,  the  PPP  center  will  have  conducted 
prefeasibility assessments of at least three proposed PPP projects, and the PPP steering group 
will have endorsed recommendations received from the PPP center.

3
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will build on a previous TA that supported the preparation of a PPP law, design 
of the proposed PPP process, institutional arrangements and development of a preliminary PPP 
pipeline.6 The TA will also build on an ongoing regional TA, which is developing a framework for 
the  transparent  identification,  costing,  contracting  and  financing  of  community  service 
obligations (CSOs) delivered by SOEs.7 The TA will be implemented through the Department of 
Treasury, which will oversee the operations of the future PPP center.  
 
11.  The  TA  will  have  four  interrelated  components:  (i)  support  for  the  PPP  center  in 
preparing a first set of pilot PPP transactions and establishing momentum and credibility in the 
PPP  program;  (ii)  support  for  the  development  of  financing  mechanisms  for  PPP  project 
preparation, through a project development facility (PDF); (iii) support for the development of 
mechanisms to secure long-term funding for the implementation of PPPs; and (iv) support for a 
CSO framework for PNG, allowing the private sector to compete for CSO contracts, and freeing 
up SOEs to adopt commercial practices, making them more viable partners for the private 
sector in future PPP transactions. 
 
12.  The government’s 2011 budget allocation for the PPP center will finance its operations, 
including core staff and intermittent inputs from external consultants who will support the center 
in its first 18–24 months of operations. As the PPP center will be formally established once the 
PPP law is enacted by parliament, it is expected that the first year of operations will be 2011. 
The  TA  will  assist  the  government  in  establishing  the  center  and  in  recruiting  technical 
specialists, and will then focus on working alongside center staff and line agencies to raise 
awareness of how PPPs can be used to deliver sector outcomes. The TA will support the 
preparation of concept notes, the structuring of project teams, and the conduct of assessments. 
As PPPs are relatively new to PNG, the TA will support a series of training courses for line 
agencies to illustrate how they can be used in their respective sectors, and work with them to 
identify potential opportunities in their investment programs.   
 
13.  Once PPP project concept notes have been approved for development, the sponsoring 
line agencies will need transaction advisors to prepare the business case, financing plans, and 
transaction structures for the projects. The input of these transaction advisors is critical to the 
development of bankable PPP projects. In order to facilitate the recruitment and financing of 
these transaction advisors, it is proposed that a PDF be created.8  Appendix 2 outlines the 
PDF’s institutional framework and operational mechanisms. The PDF would be funded by the 
government, and a budget allocation of K0.5 million has been made for 2011. The government 
intends to allocate a further K1.0 million per year for the PDF in 2012–2015. It is proposed that 
the PDF be structured as a revolving fund, with the public sector's costs associated with project 
preparation and tendering reimbursed by the winning bidder upon transaction closure. This 
                                                 
6  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to Papua New Guinea for Policies for Private Sector Development. Manila (TA 
4722-PNG, closed in December 2009). 
7  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative Phase II. Manila (TA 7430-
REG).  
8  The key benefits of structuring a PDF to finance PPP project preparation rather than using existing government 
processes in PNG are that the PDF will (i) increase transparency and efficiency in the procurement of advisors; 
and (ii) ensure that a sustainable funding source is available for PPP project preparation, as the PDF is to be 
structured as a revolving fund. Transparency would be supported through the disclosure of technical evaluations of 
consultant proposals (which is not currently the case through existing PNG procurement processes), while 
efficiency would be supported through the establishment of a prequalified panel of consultants. These consultants 
would be selected on a competitive tender basis, and would then be mobilized as needed by the PPP center to 
support PPP project preparation.

4  
revolving  structure  would  make  the  PDF  financially  sustainable.  The  TA  would  assist  the 
government  in  structuring  the  PDF  and  its  associated  management  processes.  Particular 
attention will be paid to applying the lessons learnt from the establishment of similar PDFs in 
Indonesia and India, with ADB support.   
 
14.  The TA will also support the government in assessing options for developing secure 
sources of financing for PPP projects, including through the use of sovereign wealth funds. 
Currently, project financing in PNG is dependent on the annual budget cycle, which allocates 
funding to both development and recurrent expenditure. No mechanism exists to budget for or 
to secure longer-term payment obligations within the existing fiscal management framework.9 
The establishment of a long-term funding mechanism will be essential for reducing payment risk 
and therefore the cost of future PPP agreements. The TA will work with the government to 
assess options for developing secure sources of financing for PPP projects, in both the medium 
and longer terms.  
 
15.  The fourth component of the TA will strengthen the capacity of SOEs to enter into PPP 
arrangements  and  create  new  opportunities  for  the  private  sector  to  provide  infrastructure 
services  previously  reserved  for  SOEs.  The  government  is  currently  developing  a  CSO 
framework for SOEs. The TA will support the implementation of this framework into the SOEs 
that are most likely to become future PPP partners.  
 
16.  Capacity-building efforts will be built into the TA to support the sustainability of the PPP 
program and the CSO framework, with close collaboration with line agencies, the PPP center, 
and SOEs piloting the CSO framework. At least three training courses will be conducted on PPP 
project identification and preparation, as well as training for the PPP center on the PPP process 
and management of the PDF.  
 
17.  The success of the TA will be contingent on the passage of the PPP bill in 2011 and 
continued government support and funding for the implementation of the PPP program. The 
main risk is that the government’s current reform commitment in support of increased private 
sector  participation  in  the  economy  and  reform  of  SOEs  will  lessen  in  the  context  of  the 
anticipated revenue flows from the LNG project. The ministers for treasury and finance, national 
planning,  and  public  enterprises  have  publicly  stated  their  commitment  to  using  PPPs  to 
accelerate private investment in infrastructure, and it is expected that they will actively support 
the proposed PPP legislation in Parliament. The key challenge in the TA will be to ensure that 
the spirit of transparency and accountability that has been built into the PPP policy, bill and 
institutional arrangements is upheld by the PPP center and associated government departments.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.6 million equivalent, of which $800,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, funded by the Government 
of Japan. The Government of Papua New Guinea will provide support equivalent to $800,000.10 
Detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
                                                 
9   It should be noted that trust funds, which have been widely used in PNG to save windfall revenue for specific future 
expenditure  needs,  have  to  date  been  managed  outside  the  government's  budgeting  framework,  thereby 
weakening fiscal policy control.  
10  The government contribution will be a budget allocation to finance the operations of the PPP center and the PDF.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The TA will be executed by ADB through the Pacific Liaison and Coordination Office in 
coordination  with  the  Department  of  Treasury  of  Papua  New  Guinea,  which  will  be  the 
implementing agency. The Department of Treasury will play an important role in establishing the 
PPP center and PDF and will serve as a co-chair of the CSO working group. In line with 
government processes, the executing agency for the TA will be the Department of National 
Planning and Monitoring. It is expected that the TA will begin in May 2011 and be implemented 
over a 24-month period. 
 
20.  Once the PPP law is enacted, the PPP center can be legally established. It is therefore 
anticipated that the first 8 months of the TA will be focused on supporting the establishment of 
the PPP center, working closely with its chief executive officer and steering group to launch the 
PPP program. This work will include outreach efforts, refining the PPP process and developing 
the architecture of the PDF. In subsequent phases of the TA, it is expected that the focus will be 
on supporting the preparation of PPP projects.  In addition to direct work with the PPP program 
in the first 8 months of the TA, support will also be provided to pilot the CSO framework in 
selected SOEs. This work, which will be conducted in close collaboration with the PNG CSO 
working group, will begin once the new CSO framework has been agreed by the National 
Executive Council. It is currently anticipated that this approval will be secured in the third quarter 
of 2011.  
 
21.  The TA team will be composed of technical specialists with expertise in PPP transaction 
structuring,  program  development  and  financing,  fiscal  risk  management,  public  financial 
management and CSO framework development and implementation. The sector expertise of 
the consultants will be determined by the potential PPP transactions being prepared by the 
government.  Detailed  terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  will  be  developed  in  close 
coordination  with  ADB’s  Central  Operations  Services  Office.  Individual  consultants  will  be 
engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). For the CSO component of the TA (i.e., the piloting of the CSO 
framework), which will require significant local knowledge and field presence, it is proposed that 
ADB engage a PNG-based professional services firm. The firm will be hired based on quality-
based selection. It is anticipated that 1.5 person-months of international consultant time and 6 
person-months of national consultant time will be required for the CSO component of the TA.  It 
is estimated that the TA as a whole will require a total of 19.5 person-months of international 
consultant time and 10 person-months of national consultant time. Disbursements under the TA 
will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for consultants is in Appendix 4. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to the Government 
of Papua New Guinea to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
for Facilitating Public–Private Partnerships, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 2 
PROJECT DEVELOPMENT FACILITY  
 
1.  Rationale.  Public–private  partnership  (PPP)  transactions  are  complex,  and  their 
preparation requires specialized expertise. The proposed project development facility (PDF) 
would provide funding for the engagement of transaction advisors to prepare and transact PPP 
arrangements on behalf of the government. Many countries that have developed successful 
PPP programs have done so with support from PDF facilities, notably Brazil, India, Pakistan, 
and  South  Africa.  Where  these  facilities  have  not  been  available,  or  where  inadequate 
resources have been allocated for PPP project preparation, PPP programs have faltered, and, 
in some cases, projects have been transacted with insufficient risk transfer to the private sector, 
resulting in high costs to the public sector.  
 
2.  By structuring a PDF to finance PPP project preparation rather than using existing 
government processes, it is anticipated that (i) the recruitment of the advisors will be conducted 
more efficiently and transparently,1 and (ii) the funds expended on project preparation will be 
more easily recouped by the PPP center through a success fee upon transaction completion. In 
this way, the project preparation funds can become sustainable.  
 
3.  Proposed  structure.  The  detailed  structure  of  the  PDF  will  be  developed  by  the 
technical  assistance  (TA).  It  is  anticipated  that  the  TA  will  draw  from  the  experience  of 
successful PDFs, most notably those in India and South Africa, in structuring the PDF for Papua 
New Guinea (PNG). The broad operational principles of these PDFs are illustrated in the figure 
below.

4.  The proposed PDF is to be structured as a separate fund managed by the PPP center 
and created in accordance with the Public Finances (Management) Act. PDF resources are to 
be used exclusively to finance transaction advisors to work with PPP project teams to develop 
PPP projects. The role of the PPP center in this process would be: (i) to determine which 
projects are eligible for PDF funding, (ii) to facilitate the contracting of transaction advisors 
funded through the PDF, and (iii) to manage the recovery of PDF money expended once 
projects are successfully transacted. Once contracted, transaction advisors would be managed 
by the PPP project teams and their sponsoring PNG government agency.  
 
5.  While the PDF would be under the management control of the PPP center, it is proposed 
that a financial management company be contracted by the PPP center to manage the PDF. 
This will ensure robust financial management and administration of the PDF, as the mandate of 
the  financial  management  company  will  be  to  create  an  environment  of  transparency, 
accountability, and efficiency in the use of PDF funds. The management company will prepare 
biannual accounts for the Department of Treasury and quarterly reports for the PPP center.  
 
6.  Accessing PDF funding. To facilitate the contracting of transaction advisors to prepare 
PPP  projects,  it  is  proposed  that  a  competitive  and  open  prequalification  process  be 
implemented by the government, in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  This 
prequalification process will result in a shortlist of advisors that can then be engaged by the 
center on a project-by-project basis, with agreed terms of reference for each project.   
 
7.  The PPP process, as described in the 2008 National PPP Policy and the draft PPP bill, 
has specific project assessment and approval milestones which would trigger funding from the 
PDF for further project development. The first milestone would be the endorsement of a project 
concept note by the PPP steering group and minister for treasury. This approval would qualify a 
project to move to the next stage of project development, i.e., the business case stage, and to 
access  PDF  funding  to  engage  transaction  advisors  to  prepare  the  business  case.  Once 
completed, the business case is presented to the PPP center for review and submission to the 
National Executive Council, as a second milestone in securing PDF funding. If approved by the 
National Executive Council, the project is then ready to be prepared for tender, and additional 
advisors can be recruited to prepare the transaction, which will also be funded through the PDF.    
 
8.  Replenishing the PDF fund. To ensure the sustainability of the PDF, funds expended 
in preparing PPP projects will be capitalized upon project transaction closure.  This can be done 
by adding the project preparation costs to the value of the project offered to the private sector 
partner. Upon transaction closure, the project preparation costs would then be refunded to the 
PDF, so that they can then be used to prepare the next set of projects.  All project preparation 
accounting would be the responsibility of the financial management company contracted to 
oversee the PDF accounts.   
 
9.  Size and funding.  The government has allocated $0.2 million to fund the PDF in its first 
year, 2011. Subsequent allocations of $0.4 million will be sought in each of the following four 
years 2012–2015, for a total allocation of $1.8 million.2 It is expected that this funding should be 
sufficient to prepare at least two PPP projects with a minimum value of $20.0 million each. 
During  the  first  two  years  of  the  PDF,  additional  funding  of  $0.2  million  for  PPP  project 
preparation will be provided through the TA. These funds will be managed by ADB, rather than

12  Appendix 4 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The outline terms of reference for consultants describe the main tasks in each of the four 
output categories of the proposed technical assistance (TA): (i) preparation of public–private 
partnership (PPP) projects to the business case stage, (ii) training courses on PPP project 
identification and preparation, (iii) establishment of a project development facility (PDF), and  
(iv) piloting the new community service obligation (CSO) framework in selected state-owned 
enterprises (SOEs). The Pacific Liaison and Coordination Office of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) will coordinate the TA. The required areas of expertise for international and national 
experts include PPP transaction structuring, institutional change, SOE reform, output-based aid, 
CSOs, and public financial management.  An outline of the broad terms of reference for each 
output is presented below.  
 
A.  Output 1:  Preparation of PPP Projects to the Business Case Stage (international, 
15.5 person-months; national, 2 person-months) 
2.  The PPP center is expected to be established by law and operational by the fourth 
quarter of 2011. One of its core activities in the first 12–18 months of its establishment will be to 
assess the first set of PPP project concept notes that will be submitted to it for review. The ADB 
TA will support this activity with consultants experienced in structuring PPPs in the sectors 
relevant to the first proposals. They will work alongside PPP center staff and line agencies to 
help structure PPP project teams, organize the analysis, conduct the assessments, and draft 
recommendations.  The  consultants  will  be  strong  team  players  and  have  excellent 
communication skills. Sector expertise will be required and will depend on the nature of the 
transactions under preparation, which are likely to be in key infrastructure sectors such as 
transport, power, water, and health.   
 
3.  PPPs are relatively new to Papua New Guinea (PNG), and staff in line agencies, who 
will originate PPP proposals, will need to be trained to deliver sector outcomes and to identify 
potential opportunities in their investment programs. The consultants will also support the line 
agencies to prepare PPP project concept notes and register their prospective projects with the 
PPP center.  International consultants will have graduate degrees in the areas of focus and at 
least 15 years’ professional experience in the selected sectors and areas of technical focus. 
Experience in PNG will be an advantage. National consultants will have at least 5 years’ 
experience working with government counterparts in PNG in the planning, structuring, and 
financing of public investment.  
 
B.  Output 2:  Establishment of a PPP Project Development Facility (international, 1.5 
person-months; national, 1 person-month) 
4.  The TA will support the establishment of a PDF to finance transaction advisors to 
prepare PPP projects, under the management of the PPP center. It is anticipated that the PDF 
will be modeled on those in a number of other countries, which are used to finance technical 
specialists, or the variable costs associated with project preparation and tendering. The PDF is 
expected to function as a revolving fund, with the public sector's costs associated with project 
preparation and tendering reimbursed by the winning bidder upon contract award. The TA will 
support  the  design  of  the  PDF,  including  the  development  of  policies  and  procedures  for 
procuring consultants using the fund, and its initial operations. Consultants will have expertise 
and international experience in the design and use of PDF funds. International consultants will 
have graduate degrees in the areas of focus and at least 10 years’ professional experience in 
the planning and implementation of PPP programs. National consultants will have at least 5

Appendix 4  13 
years’ experience working with government counterparts in PNG in public procurement and/or 
the planning, structuring and financing of TA programs. 
 
C.  Output 3:  Development of Options for Long-Term Financing of PPP Projects 
(international, 1 person-month; national, 1 person-month) 
5.  The TA will support the government's efforts to structure financing mechanisms for future 
PPP  projects.  This  may  include  TA  to  the  Sovereign  Wealth  Fund  Working  Group,  the 
Independent Public Business Corporation, the Department of Treasury, and other public bodies 
tasked with ensuring that future PPP projects can have access to secure, long-term sources of 
funding for capital and operational costs. Consultants will review PNG’s experience of using 
trust funds and other mechanisms to set aside funding for specific sector needs, as well as the 
experience  of  other  countries  in  establishing  infrastructure  funds  which  can  support  PPP 
projects. Particular attention will be placed on developing fully transparent funding mechanisms 
that are integrated into PNG's overall budgeting and fiscal framework. Consultants will have 
strong public financial management expertise and international experience in the design and 
use of PPP funds.  International consultants should have graduate degrees in the areas of focus 
and at least 10 years’ professional experience in the planning and implementation of PPP and 
public investment programs. Experience with structuring and management of sovereign wealth 
funds will be an advantage. National consultants should have at least 5 years’ experience 
working with government counterparts in PNG in the planning, structuring and financing of 
public investment. 
 
D.  Output 4:  Piloting the New Community Service Obligation Framework in Selected 
SOEs (international, 1.5 person-months; national, 6 person-months) 
6.  Many  SOEs  perform  community  services  for  which  they  may  or  may  not  receive 
compensation from the government. In some cases, subsidies are given to compensate for 
services  that  may  be  poorly  defined  and  rarely  measured.  Introducing  clarity  into  the 
identification, costing and compensation of CSOs will be essential to improve the performance 
of SOEs and expand private sector participation. The consultants will provide support to the 
government to implement the CSO policy and guidelines which are currently under development 
in PNG. These guidelines will provide for the identification, costing, contracting, financing and 
monitoring of CSO delivery. The consultants will support the development of simple contracting 
templates for CSOs as well as monitoring mechanisms to ensure their implementation, and will 
support the departments of treasury, public enterprise, planning, and the Independent Public 
Business Corporation in their implementation. It is anticipated that a PNG-based professional 
firm will be engaged to support the piloting of the CSO framework.  The firm should have a full-
time presence in PNG. Direct experience of working with SOEs will be an advantage.
